revisions.rev:
{{Infobox person | name = Rosalyn Landor | image = | imagesize = 200px | caption = | | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|10|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | death_date = | death_place = }} '''Rosalyn Landor''' (born 7 October 1958) is an [[England|English]] film, television, and stage actress and audio book narrator.
==Early life== Landor was born in [[London]]. She began her career at the age of seven, when she appeared in the [[Hammer Horror]] film ''[[The Devil Rides Out (film)|The Devil Rides Out]]'' (1968).<ref>Tom Johnson, Deborah Del Vecchio, ''Hammer Films: an exhaustive filmography'' (McFarland, 1996), p. 295</ref>
==Career== In 1970 she appeared with [[Susannah York]] in ''[[Jane Eyre (1970 film)|Jane Eyre]]'', playing Helen Burns.<ref>H. Philip Bolton, ''Women writers dramatized: a calendar of performances from narrative works published in English to 1900'' (2000), p. 93</ref> She co-starred in the film ''[[The Amazing Mr Blunden]]'' in 1972, based on the book [[The Ghosts]] by [[Antonia Barber]].<ref>Alan-Bertaneisson Jones, ''Fright Xmas'' (2010), p. 95</ref> She had many appearances on British and American television during the 1980s, notably as Polly Hampton in [[Thames Television]]'s ''[[Love in a Cold Climate]]'',<ref>Larry James Gianakos, ''Television Drama Series Programming: a comprehensive chronicle'' (1983), p. 134</ref> ''[[Rumpole of the Bailey]]'' (as Fiona Allways in 1983) and ''[[C.A.T.S. Eyes]]'' (starring as Pru Standfast in 1985).<ref>Jon E. Lewis, Penny Stempel, ''Cult TV: the essential critical guide'' (1996), p. 61</ref>
She guest-starred in the role of Helen Stoner in [[Granada Television|Granada]]'s definitive TV adaption ''[[Sherlock Holmes (1984 TV series)|Sherlock Holmes]]'' ([[The Speckled Band]]) opposite [[Jeremy Brett]].<ref>Ronald Burt De Waal, George A. Vanderburgh, ''The Universal Sherlock Holmes: Volume 4'' (1994), p. 1223</ref> Her theatre roles have included Sorel in [[Hay Fever]] by [[Noel Coward]] in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] in 1984 with [[Penelope Keith]] and [[Moray Watson]],<ref>Stephen Cole, ''NoÃ«l Coward: a bio-bibliography'' (Greenwood Press, 1993)</ref> and Raina in [[George Bernard Shaw|Shaw]]'s ''[[Arms and the Man]]'' at the Leicester Haymarket opposite [[Malcolm Sinclair]].<ref>Gareth Lloyd Evans, 'The Midlands' in ''Drama: the quarterly theatre review: Issues 139-154'' (1981) p. 37</ref>
In the [[United States]] Landor's television guest appearances have included ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' (in the 1989 episode "[[Up the Long Ladder]]"),<ref>Larry Nemecek, ''The Star Trek the Next Generation Companion'' (2003), p. 87</ref> ''[[Matlock (TV series)|Matlock]]'' and ''[[Hunter (U.S. TV series)|Hunter]]''.
==Personal life== Landor currently lives in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], USA where she continues to provide voices for [[Disney]] productions and is an award-winning audiobook narrator.<ref>[http://www.randomhouse.ca/author/results.pperl?authorid=67619 Rosalyn Landor] at randomhouse.ca</ref>
